abstractText: The work is devoted to gradient Gibbs measures (GGMs) of a SOS model with countable set Z of spin values and having alternating magnetism on Cayley trees. This model is defined by a nearest-neighbor gradient interaction potential. Using Külske-Schriever argument, based on boundary law equations, we give several q-height-periodic translations invariant GGMs for q = 2, 3, 4.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
It is known that macroscopic physical systems in thermodynamic equilibrium are described by Gibbs measures, that are defined through a Hamiltonian of the system [6]. A given Hamiltonian may have several distinct Gibbs measures; in that case, one says that there is phase coexistence. This corresponds to the first-order phase transitions, when several phases are thermodynamically stable at the same value of the relevant parameters (temperature, pressure, etc.)
For models (Hamiltonians) defined on low dimensional lattices, it is known (see [4, 5, 19]) non-existence of infinite-volume Gibbs measures. However, pinning a field at the origin suffices to have a well-defined thermodynamic limit in any dimension ( [4, 19]). The resulting field is completely characterized by its gradients. These infinite-volume random fields of gradients are called gradient Gibbs measures, or Funaki-Spohn states [5] (for detailed motivations and very recent results see [1, 2], [7] - [12], [17, 18,20]).
This paper is devoted to GGMs of SOS model with alternating magnetism and spin values from the set of all integers on Cayley trees.

sections.heading: 1.1 Definitions and known results
sections.text:
Let Γk = (V,L) be the uniform Cayley tree, where each vertex has k+ 1 neighbors with V being the set of vertices and L the set of edges ( [16]).
For a fixed point x0 ∈ V , Wn = {x ∈ V | d(x, x0) = n},
where d(x, y) is the distance between vertices x and y on a Cayley tree, i.e., the number of edges of the shortest path connecting x and y.
Denote by S(x) the set of direct successors of x, i.e., if x ∈ Wn, then
S(x) = {yi ∈ Wn+1 | d(x, yi) = 1, i = 1, 2, . . . , k}.
We consider models where spin-configuration ω is a function from the vertices of the Cayley tree Γk = (V, L⃗) to the set Z of integer numbers, where L⃗ is the set of oriented edges (bonds) of the tree (see Chapter 1 of [16] for properties of the Cayley tree).
For any configuration ω = (ω(x))x∈V ∈ ZV and edge b = ⟨x, y⟩ of Γk the difference along the edge b is given by ∇ωb = ω(y) − ω(x), where ωb is a configuration on b = ⟨x, y⟩, i.e., ωb = {ω(x), ω(y)}. The gradient spin variables are defined by η⟨x,y⟩ = ω(y)−ω(x) for each ⟨x, y⟩ (see [12], [13]).

The measure νw,s is called a pinned gradient measure. If q-height-periodic boundary law and the underlying potential are translation invariant then it is possible to obtain probability measure ν on the gradient space by mixing the pinned gradient measures:
Theorem 2. [12] Let a q-height-periodic boundary law l and its gradient interaction potential be translation invariant. Let Λ ⊂ V be any finite connected set and let w ∈ Λ be any vertex. Then the measure ν with marginals given by
ν(ηΛ∪∂Λ = ζΛ∪∂Λ) = ZΛ ∑ s∈Zq ∏ y∈∂Λ l ( s+ ∑ b∈Γ(w,y) ζb ) ∏ b∩Λ̸=∅ Q(ζb), (1.5)
where ZΛ is a normalisation constant, defines a translation invariant GGM on Ω∇.
The aim of this paper is to study GGMs of gradient potential constructed by an SOS model with alternating magnetism. By Theorem 2 each q-height-periodic boundary law l, which is independent on edges of tree, defines a translation invariant GGM. We find q-height-periodic boundary laws for this SOS model and use Theorem 2 to construct GGMs corresponding to these laws.

This has solutions u = 1 and u = v. Similarly, from the third equation of (2.22) we get w = 1 and w = v. Hence solutions (u, v, w) under conditions u ̸= w, v ̸= 1 have the form
(1, v1, v1), (v1, v1, 1), (1, v2, v2), (v2, v2, 1). (2.34)
Going back to (2.9) we note that solutions (2.34), with vi defined in (2.33), generate only two distinct sequences
θ ≥ 2 : . . . , 1, 1, v21 , v 2 1 , 1, 1, v 2 1 , v 2 1 , 1, 1, v 2 1 , v 2 1 , . . .
. . . , 1, 1, v22 , v 2 2 , 1, 1, v 2 2 , v 2 2 , 1, 1, v 2 2 , v 2 2 , . . .
(2.35)
By Lemma 3, Remark 1, above obtained solutions and Theorem 2 we get the following result.
Theorem 5. For the model (1.6) with graph G given in Fig. 1, the number ν4(k, θ) of 4-heightperiodic GGMs (which are NOT 2- and 3-periodic) is given by the following formula
ν4(2, θ) =  0, if θ ≤ 2 5, if θ ∈ (2, θ(3)c )
6, if θ = θ(3)c 8, if θ > θ(3)c
Remark 2. Some our results can be generalized for k ≥ 3. For example, if u = 1 and v = w then system (2.22) is reduced to vk+1− (θ+1)vk +(θ+1)v−1 = 0. This equation is very similar to (2.3).
